tive appears in a complex predicate. Communicative verbs take S-complements
marked by khi, li or IQ. They reject S-complements marked by si as well as by DQ.
Predications with these verbs limit aspect to the perfect and differentially restrict
polarity and mood, with ditransitive gue being less constrained. Complement types
with communicative verbs are embedded as direct objects. Complements never
correspond to interrogative pronouns, and only anma allows subject identity across
complement and matrix clauses with logophoric pronouns. Additional properties
emerge from consideration of each verb and its S-complements.

Concerning auxiliaries, moe constructions restrict modality and relative tense.
They allow speculative judgment epistemic forms CER ma (ólí ómóhé má' mòè íkèké
[the man PAP.CER have bicycle] ‘The man surely owned a bicycle’), DUB vba (ólí
ómóhé vbá' mòè íkèké? [the man PAP.DUB have bicycle] ‘Could the man have really
owned a bicycle?’) and bia (ólí ómòhè bíá mòè íkèké? [the man PRP.DUB have bicy-
cle] ‘Did the man actually own a bicycle?’), and assumptive judgment Hypothetical
kha (ólí ómóhé khà móé éghó' [the man PAP.HYP have money] ‘The man would have
had money’). Remaining epistemic auxiliaries (Deductive za, Resultative za, Con-
cessive rere) as well as deontic Hortative í are unacceptable.
     In moe constructions relative tense expression is grammatical. One finds ke (ólí
ómóhé ké' mòè íkèké [the man PAP.ANT have bicycle] ‘The man owned a bicycle
afterward’) as well as kpe (ólí ómòhè kpé mòè íkèké [the man PRP.SUB have bicycle]
‘The man owned a bicycle despite pending conditions’).
     moe permits preverb classes with some exceptions. Manner-demonstratives ìyó
and ìná are absolutely excluded. Phasal aspectualizers reveal a split. moe allows
phasal Additive gbo (ólí ómòhè gbó mòè íkèké [the man PRP.ADD have bicycle] ‘The
man owned a bicycle too’) and Durative se (ólí ómòhè sé mòè íkèké [the man
PRP.DUR have bicycle] ‘The man continues to own a bicycle’) but not Repetitive che
and Punctual ghe. Among boundary aspectualizers, only Past Absolute ya (ólí
ómóhé yà móé íkèké [the man PAP.PA have bicycle] ‘The man used to have a bicy-
cle’) and mo (ólí ómóhé mó' móé íkèké [the man PAP.PA have bicycle] ‘The man at
one time had a bicycle’) are acceptable. Ingressive ya, Egressive mo and Conative òó
are unacceptable.
     moe constructions selectively occur with evaluative and temporal preverbs.
They allow evaluative kuku (ólí ómòhè kùkú mòè íkèké [the man PRP.POEV have
bicycle] ‘The man afterall owns a bicycle’) and temporal kpao (ólí ómóhé kpá'ò móé

reject other preverbs belonging to the classes evaluative (duu ‘for no reason,’ woo
instead’) and temporal (tua ‘hurriedly, bobo ‘promptly’ gue ‘unexpectedly’).
     Relative to subject attributives, moe constructions are highly selective. They al-
low gbúdu, but only in its quantity sense (ólí ómòhè gbùdú mòè íkèké [the man
PRP.really have bicycle] ‘The man really owns bicycles’ / *‘The man courageously
owned a bicycle’, ólí ómòhè gbùdú mòè éghó' [the man PRP.really have money] ‘The
man really has money’). Ungrammatical are remaining subject attributives (dégbe
‘steadily,’ totóbo ‘tightly,’ kakégbè ‘perseveringly,’ dábo ‘deliberately,’ dóbo ‘mis-
takenly,’ miti ‘able,’ dúda ‘defiantly’).
     moe constructions selectively admit quantity preverbs. They allow zemi (ólí
ómòhè zèmí mòè éghó' [the man PRP.ABSI have money] ‘The man has / possesses a
lot of money’) and zeze (ólí ómòhè zèzé mòè éghó' [the man PRP.NABI have money]
‘The man has / possesses a bit of money’). But they reject Emphatic Reflexive dobo
and Collective gba.

adjuncts. It excludes affixes associated with verbs: Perseverative Ci- prefix, Facta-
tive -i suffix and Distributive -lo/lo/no suffix (*ólí ókpósó mòè-lò íkpùn [the woman
PRP.own-DS cloths] ‘The woman owns cloths’). Relative to postverbal aspectual
particles, moe is found with Temporal Perspective lee and Temporal Degree gbe.

Verb transitivity in Emai gets reshaped by detransitive predications, which reduce
the argument profile of a predication, and double object predications, which aug-
ment argument profile. Detransitives are morphosyntactically marked by preposi-
tion vbi and its complement, an erstwhile direct object. Double object predications
(with e.g. fi ‘hit’) consist of juxtaposed noun phrases, the first of which is headed by
a human or animate noun and the second by an inanimate or abstract noun. Often,
the second object serves as direct object in a corresponding transitive predication,
as examples in the following sections indicate.(1) a. òjè é          vbí ólí émà.
       Oje PRP.eat LOC the yam
       ‘Oje ate from the pounded yam.’
    b. òhí fí'        ójé úkpóràn.
       Ohi PAP.hit Oje stick
       ‘Ohi hit Oje with a stick.’12.1 Detransitive predications
Detransitive predications are characterized by preposition vbi immediately follow-
ing a lexically transitive verb. Each detransitive predication contrasts with a transi-
tive predication.(2) a. òjè é         vbí ólí émà.
       Oje PRP.eat LOC the yam
       ‘Oje ate from the pounded yam.’
    b. òjè é          ólí émà.
       Oje PRP.eat the yam
       ‘Oje ate the pounded yam.’
    c. ólì òkpòsò húá          vbí élí íkpùn.
       the woman PRP.take LOC the clothes
       ‘The woman carried some of the clothes.’
    d. ólì òkpòsò húá          élí íkpùn.
       the woman PRP.take the clothes
       ‘The woman carried the clothes.’While transitive predications show a direct object realized by a personal pronoun
(óì), detransitives exhibit a vbi complement that manifests nondeictic locative pro-

deictic locative pronouns (e.g. èvbò).(3) a. òjè é         óì / *ò.
       Oje PRP.eat it it
       ‘Oje ate it.’
    b. òjè é         vbí ò /*óì / *èvbò.
       Oje PRP.eat LOC it it yonder
       ‘Oje ate from it.’Detransitive predications exhibit additional properties when articulating sentence
aspect, aspectual interrogatives, realization verbs in series, verbal affixes, polarity
and mood as well as argument repositioning in discourse. Detransitive vbi predica-
tions restrict aspect. They inflect for Past and Present perfect but not imperfect Con-
tinuous.(4) a. òjè é         vbí ólí émà.
       Oje PRP.eat LOC the yam
       ‘Oje has eaten some of the pounded yam.’
    b. ójé é'       vbí ólí émà.
       Oje PAP.eat LOC the yam
       ‘Oje ate some of the pounded yam.’Detransitive predications reply to émé' u ‘do’ and émé' u ‘happen’ questions.(5) émé' ójé ú'-ì?     >          ò é         vbí ólí émà.

Subject corresponds to a focus position constituent but vbi complement does not.(8) a. òjè lí ó é'           vbí ólí émà.
       Oje PF he PAP.eat LOC the yam

        the yam PF Oje PAP.eat LOC it
        ‘It was the yam that Oje ate from.’12.2 Double object predications
Double object predications with shape NP1 V1 NP2 NP3 reflect two types. These types
are grounded to contrasting semantic relations underlying double object construc-
tions and the consequent participant roles of each relation. Across types, the first
object (NP2) requires a human noun that is negatively impacted by its event. In addi-
tion, NP2 manifests either of two participant roles. For type one, NP2 reflects a pos-
sessor role and for type two a causative role. Alternations between double object
predications and corresponding transitive structures direct attention to the contrast
in their semantic relations.(9) a. òlólò vbí      ójé éànmì.
       Ololo PRP.beg Oje meat
       ‘Ololo begged Oje for meat / begged for meat from Oje.’

       Ololo PRP.hit Oje stick
       ‘Ololo hit a stick on Oje / hit Oje with a stick.’
    d. òlólò só             ójé èkpà.
       Ololo PRP.smack Oje fist
       ‘Ololo smacked a fist into Oje / smacked Oje with a fist.’
